title: User Authentication
description: Verifying users are who they say they are

questions.question: Does each user have a unique username/ID?
questions.context: No shared accounts like 'admin' or 'office'. Each person needs their own login.
questions.examples: firstname.lastname format, employee ID, no generic accounts
questions.followUp: Are there any shared accounts currently? How are accounts named?
questions.discussion: All users must be uniquely identified and authenticated before accessing systems. Generic or shared accounts make it impossible to track who did what.
assessmentObjectives: Each user has a unique identifier
No shared or group accounts exist
User identities can be traced to specific individuals
redFlags: Guest accounts with access to CUI

questions.question: Do you verify user identity before granting access (passwords, MFA)?
questions.context: Users must prove who they are. Passwords are minimum, MFA is better.
questions.examples: Windows login, password requirements, multi-factor authentication
questions.followUp: What are your password requirements? Is MFA enabled?
questions.discussion: Authentication verifies the identity of users, processes, or devices as a prerequisite to allowing access. This typically involves something you know (password), have (token), or are (biometric).
assessmentObjectives: Authentication is required for system access
Password or stronger authentication is enforced
